Fascinating questions, Frank :-)

A few thoughts.


   - Will thorough test=
ing make the project take longer?  Of course it
   will.  Either in time or=
 in programmers.  After all, we are talking about
   writing more code, so =
the number of man.months is going to go up as
   well.

   The way to solve=
 this problem is to include testing in the planning
   and project features=
 and deadlines accordingly, but for having been there as
   well, I agree t=
hat it's not always possible.

   - Using debuggers less might be a good th=
ing *if* the developers find
   bugs faster.  I have seen quite a few TDD e=
nthusiasts choose not to use
   debuggers for dogmatic reasons ("because I =
read it in a book") and then
   spend hours writing tests or even println's=
 trying to reproduce a mysterious
   bug that a breakpoint would have caugh=
t in a few minutes.

   Again, the solution here is to be pragmatic:  you h=
ave two tools at
   your disposal (testing and debugger), both with their p=
ros and cons, and
   you'd be a fool to choose to use only one.
